image.altText: A family and pet dog walking through a rural property.

props.synopsis: In a year dominated by youth crime and the cost of living, environmental policy debate has been given little air time ahead of the October Queensland election.

title.children: Melanie's cattle property is the centre of her world, but she's worried about what she'll soon see from her front gate

image.altText: Lachie Neale and Dayne Zorko hold the AFL premiership cup in front of a mass of fans at the MCG

props.synopsis: Brisbane are kings of the AFL jungle again, while the Swans mourn another grand final belting. These are the key stats that decided the 2024 premiership.

title.children: Where the AFL grand final was won for the Lions, and lost for the Swans

image.altText: Three Sydney Swans AFL players embrace after losing the AFL grand final.

props.synopsis: Sydney Swans utility Robbie Fox concedes he and his teammates were dominated both physically and mentally by the triumphant Brisbane Lions in Saturday's AFL grand final.

title.children: Swans admit they 'weren't up to it' against Lions in harrowing grand final loss

image.altText: An injured Lachie Neale of the Lions is seen sitting on the floor of the stage during the Brisbane Lions Fan Day

props.synopsis: Lachie Neale has managed a heel issue for weeks, barely training, but kept turning up to lead Brisbane to a stunning grand final triumph over Sydney on Saturday.

title.children: Premiership captain celebrates in moon boot after hearing something 'pop' in grand final

image.altText: The ocean with a small island in the background, the water is red and green instead of blue due to bacteria growth

props.synopsis: The Coral Sea off Mackay in north Queensland has turned shades of brown, green and pink with bacteria dubbed "sea sawdust". It could hold the key to cracking the "puzzle" of crown-of-thorns starfish outbreaks on the Great Barrier Reef.

title.children: 'Sea sawdust' clue in controlling crown-of-thorns starfish

image.altText: A teenage girl operates her phone while sitting at a desk with a cat perched on it.

props.synopsis: Girls as young as 14 are considering diets and cosmetic procedures after bouts of cyberbullying, researchers say.

title.children: Cyberbullying a 'catalyst' for teenage girls developing eating disorders

image.altText: A composite image of flour made from lupin and lupin beans still on the plant.

props.synopsis: Lupin is traditionally used to feed cattle in Australia but aged care facilities are now adding it to their residents' food. The nutritional results experienced in the program are being labelled as "remarkable".

title.children: Turning cattle feed into nutritional flour for aged care residents

image.altText: A man wearing a tie stands indoors, looking ahead. A neutral expression on his face.

props.synopsis: Australia's airline graveyard is littered with failed carriers – with two more joining the ranks of the fallen this year. Bill Astling believes he has what it takes to break into the market.

title.children: 'You have to be insane': This man says he's starting Australia's next airline

image.altText: A Gaza and Lebanon rally in Sydney

props.synopsis: A planned day of action by pro-Palestine groups results in rallies across major Australian cities, as demonstrators call for ceasefires in Gaza and Lebanon.

title.children: Protesters rally across Australia for Gaza and Lebanon after turbulent week of Israeli military strikes

image.altText: A white man with facial difference standing outside and leaning on a brick wall

props.synopsis: A year on from the disability royal commission's final report, ABC NEWS takes a closer look at one of the biggest and most contentious proposals for change — phasing out segregated employment.

title.children: The system allowing people with disability to be paid $6 an hour

image.altText: Sold sign on Queenslander-style house in a street in Brisbane.

props.synopsis: Housing is creating wealth like never before, with property owners pocketing a record-breaking median nominal profit of $285,000 from resales in the June quarter.

title.children: Housing is Australia's multi-billion-dollar money maker — if you're selling

image.altText: Large plastic containers covered in bits of broken bricks.

props.synopsis: The UN says most fatalities were caused by a second strike that landed while first responders were arriving at the site and patients trying to evacuate.

title.children: Russia attacks hospital in Ukraine using suicide drones, killing 10

image.altText: A rocket ship taking off.

props.synopsis: NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams won't be returning home until February 2025.

title.children: SpaceX launches five-month mission to rescue two astronauts stuck in space

image.altText: A large amount of rubble, with smoke also visible rising from it

props.synopsis: Israel's attacks in Lebanon will continue for the foreseeable future, a military spokesperson says, despite confirmation Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the country's main adversary there, had been "eliminated".

title.children: Israel 'determined to keep fighting' in Lebanon despite assassinating Hezbollah chief

image.altText: albanese walks down a corridor holding papers, a grimace on his face

props.synopsis: With less than a year until the next election, the words of party elder Gough Whitlam could be ringing in Anthony Albanese's ears.

title.children: The peak of Albanese's honeymoon period was April 1 at 8:16pm. Six months later, it was a different story

image.altText: A man speaks into a microphone with his hand in the air

props.synopsis: The leader of the region's most powerful militia and Iran's strongest ally is gone, and Hezbollah, the group he headed, has been decimated by intense Israel attacks. But that doesn't mean it will die with him.

title.children: Nasrallah turned an Islamist militia into a political force that will outlive him

image.altText: Sugra Barkati walks with supporters while being escorted by armed soldiers.

props.synopsis: The 17-year-old and her brother, 11, emerge as unexpected symbols of resilience as they draw crowds to rallies across Kashmir and campaign for their father — a jailed separatist.

title.children: How a teen girl became a symbol of resistance amid tense elections in Indian-controlled Kashmir

image.altText: Darryl Gardiner

props.synopsis: Exposure to violence defined Darryl's early life, before he turned to violence himself. Today, Darryl teaches positive masculinity and uses boxing to empower communities and help break the cycle.

title.children: Darryl Gardiner: Victim turned offender turned survivor of violence now teaches positive masculinity

image.altText: Three young people sit on the floor of an office, leaning against a wall, smiling.

props.synopsis: Many Australians are neurodivergent, yet some don't disclose this to employers for fear of discrimination. So how practical is it to create a neurodivergent-friendly workplace?

title.children: One in five Australians are neurodivergent, and there are numerous barriers they face in the workplace

image.altText: Kristen and Warren look down at their son Patrick, both smiling, as he pats a cat on the head.

props.synopsis: When Andrew Leech trained as a GP 11 years ago, he thought the main issues he'd be seeing in children would be coughs and colds. He wasn't anticipating the wave of children and teens battling mental health problems.

title.children: 'It's cruel' and 'He'll grow out of it': Parents' decision to medicate their children is met with judgement

image.altText: Attractive display of fresh vegetables and fruit in grocery store

props.synopsis: Mountains of food is wasted every year in Australia, while at the same time there's been a doubling in the need for food relief. Now, there is a push on to incentivise companies to donate more.

title.children: How a tax break could help to divert manufactured food from waste to those in need

image.altText: An orange flash had been enveloped by the great uprush of water. Immense clouds of smoke, steam and spray burst into the air.

props.synopsis: Indonesia and Solomon Islands have signed up to ban the bomb. Experts say Australia's reluctance to do so could spur tension with its neighbours.

title.children: Why some argue Australia wants 'to have cake and eat it too' on nuclear weapons

image.altText: shelves without eggs at supermarket.

props.synopsis: It has been months since a deadly bird flu outbreak devastated farms, but eggs remain in short supply across the country.

title.children: Seeing empty egg shelves? It could still take some time for Australia's supply to recover

image.altText: Smiling man, white cap, pink shirt, jeans, woman, stand in front of a feature wall, with paintings of flowers and strawberries.

props.synopsis: With a number of major music events cancelled this year, some unlikely festival organisers are filling the growing gap.

title.children: Could farmers throw a lifeline to the struggling music event scene in Australia?

image.altText: Treasure Boxes volunteers  2024-06-25 09:06:00

props.synopsis: Thousands of pregnant women in Australia are going hungry with many of those too scared to ask for help, according to new research.

title.children: One in ten expecting mothers are going hungry, survey finds

image.altText: Two fisheries patrol boats on the water

props.synopsis: Fisheries officers in NSW say they are facing increasingly dangerous situations when dealing with poachers and organised crime gangs and are calling for better workplace protections.

title.children: Fisheries officers demand stab-proof vests and capsicum spray saying poachers and criminal gangs make their jobs too dangerous

image.altText: A tin shed partially submerged in floodwaters

props.synopsis: The Nepalese government says all divisions of security forces in the country, including the army, have been ordered to help in the rescue efforts.

title.children: More than 120 killed, dozens injured and stranded amid flooding and landslides in Nepal

image.altText: A couple, one wearing blue and another wearing a white t-shirt, stand in front of their roadside stall. The woman is holding

props.synopsis: A fruit and vegetable grower with a roadside stall says it's been a bumper year as people with discretionary income — and a distrust of major supermarkets — shop around.

title.children: Humble roadside stalls boom as distrust grows for Australia's two major supermarkets

image.altText: A man celebrates after scoring a try in a rugby league match

props.synopsis: With a nickname like "Brandy", it seems Paul Alamoti was always supposed to be a Panther and ahead of his grand final debut, the rising centre is hell-bent on making his mark on the game's biggest stage.

title.children: Why Penrith's new 'Brandy' won't be overawed in grand final debut

image.altText: Two men face off during a rugby league match

props.synopsis: Four years after they first met in a grand final, Penrith's clash with Melbourne is the moment the club's record-breaking dynasty comes full circle.

title.children: Penrith's grand final clash with Melbourne is a return to the beginning of their dynasty

image.altText: an old house

props.synopsis: The Moreton Bay rental was listed for sale as needing "some TLC (or a bulldozer)". A few weeks later it sold for $590,000.

title.children: A home held up with rocks cleared inspection. Months later the tenant was evicted with hours' notice

image.altText: Overhead shot of stilt houses surrounded by damaged parts from buildings floating around in a waterway

props.synopsis: Hurricane Helene caused dozens of deaths and billions of dollars' worth of destruction across several states in the south-eastern United States.

title.children: Dozens dead and millions still without power after Helene's deadly march across south-eastern US

image.altText: Adam Scott and Taylor Pendrith at the Presidents Cup

props.synopsis: America's golf stars hit back after being swept on day two, and even a shot that needed to be seen to be believed from a Korean star wasn't enough to rescue the Internationals.

title.children: Teammate's 'impossible' shot in vain as Adam Scott, Internationals fall in deep Presidents Cup hole

image.altText: Singer Slim Dusty leans on a car near Uluru

props.synopsis: Australia's "King of Country Music" performed for a number of remote Queensland towns over his 60-year career, and the communities have never forgotten it.

title.children: Why Slim Dusty's friendship with Indigenous Australia is worth singing about
